awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Role of Coupled Chemistry-climate Interactions in Internal Climate Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
A great deal of past research has been directed at understanding how coupling between climate and chemical species such as ozone and water vapor influence the climate response to anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases and ozone-depleting substances. But the importance of such coupling for year-to-year and decadal-scale variations in climate represents a key gap in our current scientific understanding of the climate system.  The project will fill this gap through analyses of both existing numerical experiments across a wide array of climate models, and from new numerical simulations explicitly for the current project. The outcomes of the project will lead to improved understanding of the role of chemistry-climate coupling in the climate system. The work has broad implications for our understanding of climate variability and change, and their related climate impacts at the surface. 

The project will provide new insights into the importance of coupled chemistry-climate interactions for climate variability in the tropics, midlatitudes, and polar regions, and at both troposphere and stratosphere. It will improve our understanding of the importance of including coupled chemistry-climate processes in designing and evaluating future large-ensemble climate simulations. In particular, it will provide a benchmark for quantifying the importance of model-to-model differences in chemistry-climate interactions in simulations of climate change. This would help establish the fidelity of the processes included in global climate models, and thus has implications for public confidence in climate models and understanding of climate science. The new knowledge about the role of coupled chemistry-climate interactions in uncertainty in climate change projections would have a range of potential implications for both society and ecosystems over various regions of the globe. The project will also provide mentoring for two graduate students from groups underrepresented in the atmospheric sciences.    

In the first part of the work, the investigators will quantify the effects of coupled chemistry-climate interactions on climate variability on year-to-year timescales. They will explore in both existing and targeted numerical climate model experiments: 1) the differences in climate variability between control simulations with and without coupled chemistry; 2) the influence of atmospheric dynamics on various chemical species; and 3) the effects of variations in chemical species on atmospheric dynamics. The second part of the work will explore the role of coupled chemistry-climate interactions in climate change as the world moves from the era of ozone depletion when ozone depleting substances increased (about 1980-1995), to ozone recovery (1995-future). The investigators will focus on 1) variability in future climate states, 2) surface climate trends on decadal timescales, and 3) uncertainty in projections of future climate changes in large-ensemble simulations of coupled chemistry-climate models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The importance of coupled chemistry-climate interactions for internal climate variability and in climate change projections is highly uncertain. The goal of the proposed research was to improve our understanding of the role of coupled chemistry climate interactions in climate change.

A partial list of outcomes includes these highlights:

1)    We found that coupled chemistry-climate interactions increase the variability of temperature by a factor of about two in the lower tropical stratosphere and to a lesser extent in the Southern Hemisphere polar stratosphere. The results highlight the fundamental role of two-way feedbacks between the atmospheric circulation and chemistry in driving climate variability in the lower stratosphere.  (Yook et al., J. Climate, 2020).

2)    We demonstrated that the post-2001 recovery in stratospheric ozone resulted in significant changes in the trends in thermal and circulation features of the SH, with climate changes extending from the stratosphere into the troposphere and surface.  The changes are generally of opposite sign to those that resulted from stratospheric ozone losses, and include warming of the SH polar lower stratosphere and weakening of the SH stratospheric polar vortex, thereby providing novel information on the emergence of dynamical impacts of the healing of the Antarctic ozone hole. (Zambri et al., Nature Communications, 2021).

3) The width of the tropics is important for climate change, particularly drying trends at the edges of the tropics; such changes have been shown to extend from the stratosphere to the troposphere.   We probed tropical width in the stratosphere using chemical tracers including nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons, which are accessible by direct measurement.  We demonstrated that unlike previously proposed stratospheric width methods, the tracer metrics perform consistently throughout the depth of the stratosphere, at all times of year, and on coarse temporal data. We also examined the effects of oscillations within the stratosphere (the quasi-biennial oscillation) on the distributions of these tracers in the troposphere and stratosphere. (Shah et al, J. Geophys. Res., 2020, 2022, and Shah, thesis, 2023).

4) The forecast potential of springtime ozone on April surface temperatures at particular locations in the Northern Hemisphere was previously reported. Using a state‐of‐the‐art chemistry‐climate model, reanalysis and observations, we extended the forecast potential of ozone on surface temperatures to aspects of the Northern Hemisphere cryosphere. Sea ice fraction and sea ice extent differences between years of March high and low Arctic stratospheric ozone extremes showed excellent agreement between an ensemble of chemistry‐climate model simulations and observations, with differences occurring not just in April but extending through to the following winter season in some locations. We found that March total column ozone was able to accurately predict the sign of the observed sea ice extent and snow depth anomalies over 70% of the time during an ozone extreme year, especially in the region of the Bering strait and the Greenland Sea, which could be useful for shipping routes and for testing climate models. (Stone et al., J. Geophys. Res., 2020).

5) The latter months of 2020 were marked by one of the largest Antarctic ozone holes on record. That such large ozone holes occurred despite ongoing ozone recovery raises questions about their origins and climate impacts. We provided novel evidence that supports the hypothesis that the ozone holes were influenced by the Australian wildfires of early 2020. We further revealed that the ozone holes were associated with widespread changes in Southern Hemisphere climate that are consistent with the established climate impacts of Antarctic ozone depletion, including a strengthening of the polar stratospheric vortex, enhanced surface westerlies over the Southern Ocean, and surface temperature changes over Antarctica and Australia.  (Yook et al., Geophys. Res. Lett., 2022).

6) Remarkable perturbations in the stratospheric concentrations of chlorine species and ozone were observed over Southern Hemisphere mid-latitudes following the 2020 Australian wildfires.   Until this work the processes producing these changes were not explained.  Here we proposed that wildfire aerosol containing a mixture of oxidized organics and sulfate increases hydrochloric acid solubility and associated heterogeneous reaction rates, activating reactive chlorine species and enhancing ozone loss rates at relatively warm stratospheric temperatures. Our results indicated that wildfire aerosol chemistry, although not accounting for the record duration of the 2020 Antarctic ozone hole, does yield an increase in its area and a 3-5% depletion of southern mid-latitude total column ozone. These findings identify a new chemistry-climate interaction and increase concern that more frequent and intense wildfires could delay ozone recovery in a warming world. (Solomon, Stone, et al., Nature, 2023).
